Objectives& The main objective of the project is to alleviate overcrowding in primary and Description: secondary schools through school construction and provision of furniture and equipment. The project will also lay the groundwork for broader education reform and system reconstruction.
Component 1: School Construction (US$97.25 million) will finance the construction, equipping and furnishing of about 82 new schools (1,500 classrooms). Component 2: Institutional Strengthening for System Development and Reform (US$1.80 million) will finance a comprehensive program to support education system development and the design of a national school construction and maintenance program. Component 3: Project Management (US$O.95 million) will finance the costs of implementing the project and further build the capacity of the project management team in the Ministry of Education.
Benefitsand Risks Benefits:The project will directly benefit approximately 57,000 students, by financing the construction, furnishing and equipping of about 82 new schools (around 1,500 additional classrooms). This will help improve the learning environment which currently suffers from highly congested school facilities, and increase access for children currently not enrolled in school. The school buildings constructed under this project will serve as a model for other agencies interested in assisting in school construction. The Ministry of Education's institutional capacity will be strengthened to carry out policy and system development for reform. Inaddition, the project will create substantial local employment: civil works for school construction will be carried out by Iraqi contractors, creating an estimated 980,000 person-days of employment.
Risks: The project will be implemented in a high-risk environment. The major risks to the project are the unstable security and political environment and the limited capacity o f the government and private sector. In previous education projects in Iraq, capacity building provided by Bank staff during supervision missions has helped accelerate project preparation and implementation. A full presentation of risks, along with measures to mitigate their impact, i s provided in Section F.

A. BACKGROUND AND STRATEGY
Country Background
1. Iraq-which enjoys both abundant natural resources and skilled human resources-attained the status o f a middle-income country in the 1970s. B y the early 198Os, income per capita reached over US$3,600, and the country's infrastructure and systems o f education and healthcare were considered the best in the region. Since that time, two decades o f successive wars and a repressive state-dominated economic system have stifled growth and crippled basic infrastructure and social services. Internationaltrade sanctions imposed in 1991took a further toll on the economy. B y 2002, GDP per capita had fallen to about US$SOO. The invasion by Coalition forces in March 2003 brought the economy to a near stand-still-resulting ina further decline inthe GDPper capita to an estimated US$518. A UN-World Bank Joint Needs Assessment prepared in mid-2003 pointed out that Iraq's human development indicators were among the lowest in the region. 2. Since 2003, Iraq has made some progress on both the political and economic fronts. The country i s undergoing a complex political transition, taking steps towards a constitutionally-elected government. Iraq's GDP, driven by a partial recovery o f the oil sector and high world oil prices, rebounded by nearly 50 percent in 2004 to about US$942. However, GDP i s projected to increase by only about 2.6 percent in 2005.' Continued violence and instability have slowed reconstruction efforts, increased security costs, impeded investment, and hampered efforts to further increase oil production. Many basic services have not yet returned to their pre-2003 level, and unemployment i s estimated at 30 percent or more.
3. Ongoing insecurity has also slowed the implementation and disbursement of donor- financed projects, despite pledges of about US$32 billion at the October 2003 Donor Conference in Madrid. Donors have deposited about US$1 billion in the International Reconstruction Fund Facility for Iraq (IRFFI). This includes about US$400 million in the World Bank Iraq Trust Fund (ITF), almost all of which was committed to nine projects in 2004, including two projects inthe education sector.
4. One of Iraq's main challenges i s to build political legitimacy and credible and inclusive institutions needed for stability and sustainable economic prosperity. In this context, restoring and improving basic services are essential for improving the quality of life, increasing government credibility, and restoring stability. International experience with reconstruction in conflict-affected countries has shown that well-targeted government expenditures on social services, including education, are particularly important for reducing the risk of further conflict.

The Education Sector 5. Only five months after the May 2003 invasion, Iraq's primary and secondary schools opened for the 2003104 school year. Despite ongoing insecurity and uncertainty, the school system continued to operate through a second academic year, and has now commenced a third. Iraq's national budget financed the recurrent costs of sustaining the education system in the 2004/05 school year. Slower than expected economic recovery limited public resources available for capital investment. International donors have provided supplemental support for school rehabilitation, textbooks, basic learning materials, furniture and equipment, and teacher training. 6. The resumption o f schooling and continuity o f learning are major achievements. Nevertheless, the educational system continues to face major challenges in terms of access, quality, and efficiency. Massive backlogs accumulated over the past two decades in school construction and maintenance, human resource development, and policy and system development are the key underlying problems. Educational strategy documents prepared over the past two years cite school overcrowding as the single most pressing problem confronting the Iraqi educational system. 7. School Overcrowding. Some six million children are enrolled in 19,000 primary and secondary institutions accommodated in 14,000 physical locations. Very few schools have been built in Iraq since the mid-1990s. As a result, more than 2,630 primary schools and 750 secondary schools operate in double shifts using shared facilities, and 254 primary and 56 secondary schools operate in triple shifts. Table 1, using relatively conservative pupi1:classroom ratios o f 40: 1 at the primary level and 36:l at the secondary level, indicates that there i s a deficit o f at least 107,000 classrooms to accommodate the 2003/4 enrolment.

9. Poor and overcrowded facilities are contributing to low school enrolment rates. Despite having achieved universal primary enrolment by 1980, Iraq's primary Net Enrolment Rate (NER) declined to 86 percent in 2003/04, implying that at least 500,000 children of primary school age- mostly girls in rural areas and both boys and girls in the more densely populated urban areas-are not registered in primary school. Girls' net enrolment rates in some rural areas are as low as 30-40 percent, and attendance rates are even lower. Lack of facilities and the poor and highly congested condition of schools are among the key factors responsible for the low enrolment and attendance rates inmany areas. 10. Only two governorates (Basra and Najaf) have primary NER above 90 percent. The lowest NER tend to be in the predominantly rural governorates of Muthanna, Wasit, and Missan, where over a quarter of primary school-age children are not in school. Thus, while these governorates have among the lowest pupi1:classroom ratios, they have a high need for additional classrooms when taking account of childrennot enrolled in school. 11. Fewer than three-quarters of primary students continue to secondary school, with transition rates below 50 percent in rural areas. The NER for secondary education, at 36 percent (as low as 8 percent for girls in rural areas), i s among the lowest in the region. Just over three-quarters of those who enroll in secondary schools complete the cycle, with a slightly higher survival rate for girls as well as children inrural areas.
12. Overcrowdedfacilities are also a main cause of system inefficiency. Although pupi1:teacher ratios for primary and secondary schools are relatively low at about 20:1, pupi1:classroom ratios are high at 44:l. Over 270,000 teachers employed in primary and secondary schools have access to only 134,000 classrooms, creating inefficiencies in teacher utilization, because only half the teachers employed have access to a classroom at any given time. 13. Education Policy and System Development. The rigidity of a highly centralized authoritarian administration and decades of isolation from international experience in education policy and system development have left Iraqwith an education system largely unchanged since the 1970s. Throughout Iraq, there is a strong awareness that the education system requires a major overhaul to play a significant role in the transition to a more market-oriented and competitive economy and a democratic and accountable political system. It i s likely to take several years to develop the national consensus needed for fundamental education system reform. Thus, the current transitional environment creates a window of opportunity for capacity building in policy and system development. There is a growing recognition in the MOE of the value of developing the human and institutional resources that will be required to conceptualize, negotiate, and implement system reform, including eventually new legislation and procedures. The MOE i s seeking assistanceboth to manage the interim policy and strategy adjustments that will be required to nurse the system through the next few years, and to lay the groundwork for more substantial system development that will promote better alignment with the national consensus on development strategy as it emerges.  5
Government Strategy and Donor Involvement 14. In 2003, under the Coalition Provisional Authority and Governing Council, the MOE was one of the first ministries to organize a donor meeting (November 2003) and produce a sector strategy, which identified the most urgent needs and indicated possible directions for future reform. Under the subsequent government (Interim Iraqi Government), the MOE produced an update of the strategy, focusing mostly on quantifying capital and human development backlogs, especially teacher training. 15. During 2005, under the Iraq Transitional Government, the MOE worked to strengthen its capacity to lead the education sector and improve donor coordination. During an education sector donor meeting in Amman in July 2005, the Minister of Education presented an overview of needs and priorities to international partners and compiled a list of all donor activities. InAugust 2005, the MOE launched an Education Sector Working Group (ESWG) for coordinating the planning and implementation of educational projects supported by various agencies and non-governmental organizations (NGO). The MOE is in the process of revising its education strategy paper, which will provide a framework for all donor support. One of the key challenges i s to move from a needs- based approach to a more strategic framework. Another challenge i s to build better linkages between general and higher education.
16. The United States (US), United Nations (UN),and World Bank have been the main donors supporting the education sector since April 2003 (see Table 2 and Annex lo). The U S has provided support mainly through the United States Agency for InternationalDevelopment (USAID) and mainly for school rehabilitation, ranging from minor repairs to major reconstruction. The UN has provided assistancethrough the UNITF and through direct UNcontributions, involvingmainly UNICEF, UNESCO, and UN Habitat, and supporting a wide range of activities, including school supplies, textbooks and learning materials, equipment, capacity building, and school rehabilitation. The World Bank, using the World Bank ITF, has focused on emergency textbook printing for 2004/05, major school rehabilitation, school construction, and capacity building for the sector.
17. Since the first donor meeting in November 2003, donors have coordinated their support for the education sector through conference calls, regular meetings, and a coordinating structure that evolved into the ESWG. As a result, significant interventions have been complementary. For example, the UN and the U S provided financing for textbooks for the 2003/04 school year. The World Bank financed all textbooks for the 2004/05 school year; while the UN provided school supplies and school kits for every student. For the school year 200906, both the UNand the World Bank (through cost savings from the previous year) are contributing financing for textbooks. Inthe area of school rehabilitation, the needs are so great that there is little possibility of overlap or duplication. The MOE reports that 3,820 schools have benefited so far from various levels of repair or rehabilitation; yet this represents less than a third of the overall backlog in school rehabilitation.
18. In addition to the main donors, there are a number of national and international NGOs providing support for the education sector. The MOE i s also reaching out to other international development partners, including the Japan Bank for International Cooperation and the Islamic Development Bank, both of which participated in the appraisal mission for the Third Emergency EducationProject and have expressedan interest inproviding parallel financing.

B. BANK RESPONSEAND STRATEGY
19. Under the First InterimStrategy Note for Iraq, the Bank allocated US$lOO million-about 25 percent of ITF resources-to two emergency education projects. The US$40 million Emergency Textbook Provision Project (ETPP) financed the printing of textbooks for primary and secondary schools in 2004/05, while the Emergency School Construction and Rehabilitation Project (ESCRP) i s financing the rehabilitation of some 143 schools and the constructionof some 117 new schools.
20. In September 2005, the Bank`s Executive Directors discussed a Second InterimStrategy Note, which builds on the experience of the First InterimStrategy Note and provides a framework for up to US$500 million in IDA resources and additional ITF resources. The overall objective of the Second Interim Strategy Note i s to help buildefficient, inclusive, and accountable institutions as needed for stability, good governance, and sustainable economic prosperity. Under the umbrella of institution building, the Bank Group's work program is organized into four pillars: (i) restore basic service delivery; (ii) enable private sector development; (iii) strengthen social safety nets; and (iv) improve public sector governance. Pillar one, restoring basic services, explicitly includes a commitment to "addressing access, equity, and quality in the education system" through eliminating backlogs in school construction and through institutional strengthening for reform. 21. Within this framework, the Bank's strategy for education in Iraq has three main objectives, drawing on its world-wide experience with reconstruction inconflict-affected areas, namely:
0 to promote stability by addressing basic needs for continuity of learning, such as emergency provision of textbooks;
0 to address the key factors undermining equity and efficiency: rehabilitation and construction of schools; and
0 to strengthen system governance by building capacity for project implementation, for system development, and for longer-termreform. 22. These three objectives are being implemented simultaneously and complement each other. Provision of textbooks i s accompanied by support for textbook revision and capacity building for curriculum reform. School rehabilitation and construction activities introduce international standards for procurement and financial management, more systematic monitoring, and greater transparency in reporting. System development activities build on the experience, competence and systems developed through project implementation. Another project that is under consideration i s the proposed ITF-financed Capacity Building for Education and Training Reform Project. This will  7
help lay the groundwork for substantial reform of the education and training system to promote better alignment of education and training with the needs of a changing labor market and an economy intransition.
Bank-FinancedEducationProjectsand Lessons Learned 23. The ETPP, approved in May 2004, was the first ITF-financed sectoral project in Iraq, responding to an urgent request from the MOE to finance the printing and distribution of 69 million textbooks for all primary and secondary schools for the 2004/05 school year. The project benefited six million primary and secondary school pupils. It was also designed to maximize local content and employment by contracting local printers to the maximum extent possible, taking into consideration the quantity of paper available in Iraq. Competitive bidding procedures led to cost savings of about US$9 million, which were used to procure additional textbooks for 2005/06. Activities are also underway to strengthen capacity for textbook development and production, linkedto curriculumreform. 24. The ESCRP (US$60 million), approved in October 2004, aims to alleviate school building hazards and school overcrowding by constructing 117 new schools and by rehabilitating 143 schools needing urgent repair, covering all 18 governorates of Iraq. The project directly benefits about 130,000 pupils (7 percent of pupils in overcrowded or damaged schools.) The use of local firms for design and supervision and local construction companies for rehabilitation and construction i s also creating substantial near-term employment. Project implementation is on schedule: 135 schools have been rehabilitated, and an additional 9 schools will be rehabilitated by the end of 2005. Local consultants are in the process of designing construction of the first 31 new schools, for which procurement will take place before the end of 2005. The Bank i s also supporting the MOE indeveloping a broad strategic framework for reform and a donor coordination strategy.
25. The ETPP and ESCRP have shown that emergency education projects with simple designs can be implemented under the current circumstances. The MOE has demonstrated its capacity to satisfactorily implement emergency operations. Also, the Bank i s able to carry out project supervision, despite the current limitations on access of international staff to Iraq. The Bank has relied heavily on a cadre of excellent local staff and consultants in Iraq for daily supervision and monitoring, and has met project counterparts outside Iraq on a quarterly basis for intensive supervision missions. Well-designed project launch workshops have also proven to be highly effective in facilitating implementation.For example, the ESCRPproject launch workshop gathered MOE focal points from 17 governorates and helped build MOE staff capacities in the areas of procurement, financial management, disbursement, and monitoring. Workshop participants finalized bidding documents for school rehabilitation, and contracts were advertised shortly thereafter, allowing a prompt start of the project.
26. Implementing projects through Iraqi ministries has numerous benefits, including greater ownership and sustainability and negligible security costs. Under the ESCRP, the unit costs for school rehabilitation have been 30 to 40 percent below comparable projects implemented by donor agencies. Most importantly, recipient-executionstrengthens overall institutional capacity. Under the ETPP, the MOE used, for the first time, competitive bidding procedures that meet international standards. Recognizing the cost savings achieved, the MOE is now applying these procedures to textbooks financed from their own budget. Underthe ESCRP, the MOE i s usingIraqiprivate sector building contractors and design and supervision services from private consultants, an innovation that results in more efficient use of MOE technical resources, strengthens the capacity of the MOE in every governorate, and fosters the growth of the private sector. Similarly, new procedures for transparent financial management and reporting are setting examples for ministry practices. The Bank's investment projects thus have a wider impact on overall policy and institutional capacity.  8
27. The ETPP and ECSRP have also shown the value of linking policy reform to practical activities. For example, the ETPP complements provision of textbooks with a component to build capacity for textbook development and production according to international best practice and linked to curriculum reform. 28. Lessons Learned from Reconstruction in Conflict-Affected Environments. The World Bank education strategy in Iraq and the proposed project reflect lessons from World Bank experience in conflict-affected countries, such as Afghanistan, East Timor, Bosnia-Herzergovina, Algeria, Sierra Leone and Kosovo, as well as in West Bank and Gaza. First, experience has shown the importance of promptly resumingnormal schooling and the value of early and visible impact. A second lesson i s the importance of institutional development in the ministry to lay the basis for wider system reform. A third lesson is the importance of early and effective donor coordination under the leadership of the government.
Rationale for Bank Involvement 29. The Bank has considerable experience insupporting large-scale school rehabilitation and/or construction projects in conflict-affected settings. The Bank was the lead agency for education in the UNWorld Bank Joint Needs Assessment, working closely with UNagencies and USAID. Soon after the appointment of a Minister of Education in 2003, the Bank developed a strong working relationship with the MOE, including weekly conference calls to provide advice on key policy and reform issues. The strong Bank-MOE dialogue led to the financing of the ETPP, the Bank's first ITFoperation inIraq implementedby a line ministry. 30. Emergency education projects in conflict-affected countries usually focus on rehabilitation, as has been the case in Iraq over the last two and a half years. However, the situation in Iraq also warrants an early focus on new school construction, because school overcrowding i s a major impediment to increasing access to basic education and improving the quality and efficiency of the education system. The World Bank i s one of few donors at this time with a substantial commitment to school construction (Table 2). 31. The Bank is one of the few donors that finance projects implemented by Iraq's own ministries, resulting in better policies and stronger institutional capacity at both the central and governorate levels. The Bank's support for school construction and related policy reform will strengthen the MOE's capacity to design and implement a large-scale national school construction program financed in the future by other donors and Iraq's own budget. The Bank will also support the MOE to develop a national school maintenance program. The Bank i s thus positioned to provide support for the key policy and system development dimensions that will improve overall governance of the education sector.
C. D E T A I L E D PROJECTDESCRIPTION
Project Objective 32. The principal objective of the project i s to alleviate overcrowding inprimary and secondary schools through school construction and provision of furniture and equipment. The project will also lay the groundwork for broader school reformand systemreconstruction.  9
Project Components 33. The project, which will amount to SDR 69.1 million (US$lOO million equivalent), i s a follow up to two ITF-financed projects in Iraq and draws extensively upon their experience. Summary and detailed cost tables are provided inAnnex 1.The project will have three components:
Component 1: School Construction (US$97.25 million, including contingencies) 34. The component will finance the construction o f buildings and provision o f furniture and equipment for about 82 new primary and secondary schools in 15 governorates, creating around 1,500 additional classrooms to accommodate some 57,000 students3.There are over 300 sites that have already been designated for schools by local authorities throughout the country. Allocation of resources across governorates was agreed at project appraisal on the basis o f (i) wide coverage, to address part o f the backlog in each regional directorate, including the construction o f one complete, modem secondary school in each governorate; and (ii) increased allocation to governorates where data indicate greater congestion, lower net enrolment rates, or a higher proportion o f "mud schools." Identification o f specific sites in each directorate will be finalized at the project launch workshop usingthe following criteria: (i) targeting sites in communities where enrolment rates are lowest and/or pupi1:classroomratios are highest; and (ii) preference for sites that will reduce gender disparities. Final site selection will be limited to those that conform to basic school planning criteria, are accessible to necessary services, and are vacant and therefore involve no population resettlement. Component 2: Institutional Strengthening for System Development and Reform (US$1.80 million, including contingencies) 35. This component will finance development of a comprehensive program to support system development and strengthen governance at the central and directorate levels of the MOE. This component builds on the improved governance capacity established through ETPP and ESCRP implementation, and will include the design of a school construction and maintenance program to systematically address the school construction backlog. Other system development activities will focus on building the human and institutional capacity to conceptualize, design, operationalize and implement policy and system reform. Three target areas for system development have been agreed with the MOE: (i) strategic planning for system development; (ii) options for teacher policy management (such as recruitment, training and development, deployment and utilization); and (iii) institutional strengthening for curriculum development and reform. The project will develop and implement a comprehensive program to support system development and strengthen governance at central, regional, and directorate levels.
36. The specific system development-related activities will be defined during the project launch workshop, and will include: (i) technical assistance for studies and data collection conducted in Iraq in key policy areas relating to policy and system reform, teacher policy, curriculum development and physical infrastructure planning, construction and maintenance; (ii) institutional and organizational development, including information and management systems, management development practices and policies, and policy options modeling; (iii) learning from experience of other countries through study tours, international seminars, and conferences; and (iv) short term training programs in key policy areas for selected officials.

Component 3: Project Management (US$0.95 million, includingcontingencies) 37. Project management will be the responsibility of the MOE under the leadership of the Project Management Team (PMT) currently supervising implementation o f the ESCRP and the ETPP. The PMT i s an integral part of the MOE, staffed by MOE officials assigned to the project team on a full-time basis. To accommodate the additional demands o f this project, the capacity of the PMT will be supplemented in the areas of team leadership (appointment of a Deputy Team Leader), progress monitoring and reporting, financial management, and procurement. Project management costs will include the provision of furniture, equipment, technical assistance, and training necessary for the management o f the project, as well as operating costs of the PMT. Project DesignIssues 38. School Design Standards. The designs used for existing schools reflect the norms and educational approaches o f the 1970s when there was a massive expansion of physical capacity in the system. However, they do not generally provide for media centers or computer laboratories, and the science laboratories at the secondary schools were designed for teacher demonstration rather than pupil participation in experiments. The present designs result in classrooms that average 43 square meters, smaller than international standards require, because the designs assume relatively low pupi1:classroom ratios of around 30:1, while the average pupi1:classroom ratio i s presently 44:l. The MOE recognizes the need to ensure that schools built for the new Iraq reflect international norms, the most appropriate designs, the most efficient use o f space, and, as far as possible, accommodate the needs o f disabled students and teachers. Rather than proposing standard designs, this project will employ new design standards for schools, furniture, and equipment that meet the latest international norms and, in the case o f schools, provide for larger classrooms of about 52 square meters. The switch from standard designs (a set of standard plans) to design standards - a set of technical specifications that incorporate international norms - provides for greater flexibility to accommodate varying local conditions while still ensuring a degree of uniformity and institutions that meet the pedagogical requirements of 21st Century education. The MOE will refine these design standards through the project, and apply them to all future school construction. 39. National School Construction and Maintenance Program. The MOE has approached the Bank for support to strengthen its capacity to plan and implement a national school construction and maintenance program to address the schools backlog. While the education system in the 1980s had the capacity for planning and implementing large-scale capital works programs, this institutional capacity has diminished over the last decade. Approaches to school construction in the past relied heavily on the public sector and on centrally planned large-scale construction programs. In recent years responsibility for school construction and maintenance has been devolved to the regional directorates, and there exist in each directorate school construction and maintenance divisions with competent staff. The Bank i s able to draw on its international experience and build on the experience, implementation mechanisms and institutional capacity developed in the ESCRP to support development o f a national school construction and maintenance program. Moreover, the implementation o f the ESCRP and this project will result in every directorate having teams of seasoned professionals with experience in overseeing school construction projects using modem design standards and construction methods. This will position them well to contribute to the development o f a national program to address the massive construction backlog and plan for maintenance and expansion o f the system. 40. School construction will include classrooms, facilities (such as laboratories, libraries, and administration centers), and site development for basic recreation facilities and services. The MOE has a strong preference for construction o f complete schools that provide a model for future construction programs, rather than a modular approach that would focus initially on classrooms  11
with a future plan to add subsidiary buildings (administration centers, laboratories, libraries, and multi-purpose halls). The MOE recognized the risk that other priorities could result in extended postponement of completion of schools, and opted for a smaller number of complete schools. E. FINANCIAL AND ECONOMICJUSTIFICATION
80. Macroeconomic framework: Despite the tremendous difficulties currently facing Iraq, the medium-term economic outlook is satisfactory as long as oil production continues to expand and world oil prices remain at favorable levels. The fiscal condition should be sustainable in the mediumterm provided the government controls the growth of recurrent expenditures, and revenues, which depend on oil production and price, do not fall. The recent International Monetary Fund (IMF)report (July 2005) shows that in2004, GDP increasedby nearly 50 percent, driven mainly by the recovery of the oil sector. After a continuous decline during the last decade, per capita income rose to US$940, still less than a quarter of what Iraq used to have two decades ago. Overall GDP growth is projected to reach 17 percent in 2006 and then decline gradually to 7 percent and continue at that level up to 2010. 81. Allocations to education: The combined budgets of MOE and Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (MHESR) have a very low share of 4.5 percent in the government budget in 2005; it is by far the lowest when compared to other countries in the region where the ratio i s twice or three times that in Iraq. This is mainly due to the fact that the government budget for 2005 (ID36 trillion) reflects post-conflict conditions with public subsidy programs (card ration), state-owned enterprise (SOE) subsidies, and war damage compensation  18
making up 60 percent o f the budget. The share of salaries, which has doubled from 2004, was only 16 percent o f the budget. Capital goods acquisition (e.g. armored vehicles) and other security related materials take up 10 percent of the operational budget. The Iraqi Transitional Government's National Development Strategy includes economic reform policies such as privatization, restructuring and phasing out of SOE subsidies. If these policies are effectively implemented, more resources will be freed up and the financial share of the line ministries, including education, can increase. 82. The MOE budget: The government policy in 2004 and 2005 was to keep the education system functioning, and thus top priority was given to operational expenditure. The government relied on international organizations, donors, and bilateral support to finance the reconstruction efforts. The M O E budget for 2005 (ID1.3 trillion) consists almost entirely o f operational expenditures (92 percent), and a substantial proportion o f the operational expenditure goes to salaries (95 percent). Services and asset maintenance make up the rest of the operational budget. Allocation for investment expenditure in the MOE budget i s a relatively small amount of ID100 million (8 percent o f MOE budget). The project will have a significant fiscal impact when compared to the current size of the MOE investment budget. 83. A range of donor agencies has been involved in supporting education in Iraq since May 2003, with the U S as the major bilateral partner, and the UN and the World Bank providing assistance largely through the two trust funds. The World Bank ITF-financed projects, with a total value o f US$lOO million, have focused on emergency textbook printing for 200415, school rehabilitation and construction, and capacity building; and the UN financed programs o f US$80 million have targeted a wide range o f activities, including school rehabilitation, supplies, equipment, and capacity building.While these programs represent a good start, they are small when compared to the sector's needs (US$4.8 billion) assessedby the UN/WB Needs Assessment Study (October 2003). 84. Budgetary and financial management: Iraq lacks adequate financial management mechanisms and data reporting frameworks; it also lacks a fully functional statistical reporting system. Education financial management has suffered from problems ranging from the poor security environment and difficulties in communication with the education authorities in the governorates to the non-transparent recording o f financial transactions that affected the MOE's ability to allocate resources effectively or to track overall spending and outcomes. The project will provide technical support to address urgent problems such as the fragmentation o f the budget, inadequate reporting o f expenditures financed both by the government budget and donors, and weak accountability. Some basic institutional issues will need to be resolved regarding the role o f various actors in addressing issues of budgeting and financial management. 85. Institutional capacity: The project will pioneer new design standards for school construction that will be incorporated into the national school construction and maintenance program. The modus operandi using recipient implementation with support for institutional strengthening for better implementation, system development and reform will provide a model for other donor financed projects. 86. Policy reforms and system eficiency: There is a growing recognition in the MOE of the value of developing the human and institutional resources that will be required to conceptualize, negotiate and implement financial system reform and policy options. The project will support the MOE to manage the interim policy and strategy adjustments that will be required to improve the efficiency o f the system and to lay the groundwork for more substantial system development that will promote better efficiency of expenditure and provide policy alternatives. There are substantial savings that can be generated from improving the efficiency o f the education system and  19
streamlining the teaching force that would free up resources for part of the enormous need for reconstruction and upgrading the education system inIraq.
87. Cost-effectiveness of school construction standards: The designs used for existing schools reflect the norms and educational approaches of the 1970s when schools were designed for teacher demonstration rather than pupil participation in experiments. Classrooms are on average smaller (43 square meters) than international standards recommend because they were constructed on the basis of a relatively low student:classroom ratio of around 30:1, while the current average is 44: 1. The project will develop and refine an approach to school design with efficient utilization of space and up-to-date design standards. For example, the project will introduce standardized materials schedules to encourage the utilization of economically available components throughout the country, using modular design', an economical structural span, appropriate orientation of buildings to maximize benefits from the local environment to reduce energy costs, and appropriate local buildingmaterials andbuildingtechnology to increasedurability andreduce maintenance costs. 88. Project's impact on employment creation:The school construction under the project will be implemented by local contractors in the governorates and would generate approximately 41,000 person-days inconsultant services and over 980,000 person-days of work inthe construction sector. The conflict and the economic decline have destroyed a large number ofjobs inthe formal and non- formal sectors and resulted in an unemployment rate of approximately 30 percent. At present, the demand for labor is too low to absorb the continuous demographic increase and workers already unemployed. The project will increase the demand for labor in the construction sector and, where building materials are bought from local manufacturing firms, the increase will also extend to workers inthese firms. 89, Fiscal impact of the project: The project would have a significant impact on the capital expenditure of MOE. The project would be implemented over three years (2006-2008) with an average of ID50 billion a year. These annual allocations represent 42 percent of the annual investment expenditure of MOE. The relatively small allocation of investment expenditure reflects the government policy of giving top priority to operational outlays to keep the education system functioning while depending heavily on foreign donors in the reconstruction efforts. The project allocations represent about 3 percent of the total MOE budget and have a marginal fiscal impact on the overall education budget.
90. Project sustainability: The project mainly finances building of new primary and secondary schools. School construction is a one-time investment to address accumulated backlogs. The project includes provision for financing equipment and furniture for all new schools. Given that the new schools will largely accommodate staff and students reassigned from existing overcrowded schools, the project will not significantly increase the recurrent costs in terms of teacher salaries or management costs. Maintenance of buildings and equipment of the project schools will be covered by the MOE recurrent budget. Future maintenance costs of the project schools will be a very small share of the overall MOE operational budget and budget projections show that they do not constitute a sustainability problem. However, the sustainability of maintenance costs of all schools in Iraq (14,000 schools) could become an issue during the short to medium term, as two thirds of the public budget goes to transfers and subsidies and the share of the line ministries is quite small (MOE share i s 3.5 percent of the government budget in 2005). The expected increase in oil exports and the economic reform policies that are being introduced, such as privatization, restructuring of SOEs, and phasing out subsidy programs, are expected to stimulate sustainable growth over the mediumterm and provide fiscal space for such types of expenditure.

Introductionand Background The education system in Iraq that flourished in the 1980s went through a major financial crisis in the 1990s as a result o f three major wars and over a decade of sanctions. This led to massive degradation and deterioration of the education system and an accumulated backlog in capital development and maintenance. This has resulted in: A sharp decline in education expenditure: Education expenditure declined dramatically during the 1990s as a result of the war and the economic embargo. In 1988/89, the education sector budget was US$2.5 billion (about 6 percent o f GDP) and expenditure per student was US$623. Over the 1993-2002 period, the Oil for Food Program (OFFP) provided US$1.744 billion for the education sector, mainly for supplies and equipment and salaries, while other recurrent expenditures were covered by the very limited government resources. As a result, expenditure per student declined to an extremely low level, reaching US$35 by 2003. Duringthe last two years, more resources were allocated to education and in2005, expenditure per student increasedto US$170. A substantial decline in teacher salaries: The OFFP did not include cash payments and, as a result, the funds were not used for meeting recurring expenditure o f any kind. This inturn added to the financial crisis o f the sector and led to a substantial decline in teaching staff salaries. The average teacher salary fell over the decade o f the nineties from US$500 per month to US$5-30 per month and this led to a massive exodus o f trained teachers and other qualified academic and non-teaching staff. However, a new salary structure that was established in 2004 increased the monthly average salary o f teachers to US$120 and it was raised again to US$200 in 2005.
0 A signifcant deterioration in system eficiency: The extremely low allocations to the sector led to rapid deterioration in all aspects o f the education system. New students were admitted to existing schools because there were no funds to build new schools. One-third o f the schools are operating in double and triple shifts to accommodate additional students. This has also contributed to an increase in dropouts and repetition. The crowded classrooms, shortage of teaching and learning materials, and the loss o f qualified teachers got much worse after the last war due to the damage to the education institutions and looting of its equipment and physical infrastructure. Rationalefor InvestinginEducation Investment in restoring the education system is crucial to Iraq. There are substantial benefits from investment in education, especially in conflict-affected societies. Investment in education has an immediate positive effect on society in conflict, because a well-functioning school system provides a sense o f normalcy and encourages the population to invest in the future. Iraq has strong human capital base that will be key to the task o f restoring the education sector. Education increasesproductivity, raises income, and reduces poverty: The Household Survey (HS) in Iraq conducted in 2004 showed a strong correlation between income level and education attainment. People with higher education in Iraq enjoy better economic conditions than people with little or no education. The majority (78 percent) o f the households in the lowest income quintile have no education or completed only primary school, whereas more than one-third (36 percent) o f those who fall in the highest income category have secondary and higher education (Table la).  46

Sustainability of the project: The project covers primarily building o f new primary and secondary schools. School construction i s a one-time investment to address accumulated backlogs. The plan includes provision for financing equipment and furniture for all new schools. Given that the new schools will largely accommodate staff and students reassignedfrom existing overcrowded schools, the project will not significantly increase the recurrent costs in terms o f teacher salaries or management costs. School maintenance i s currently the responsibility o f the MOE, for which provision i s made in the annual budget. The capacity building component will include technical assistance for the development o f a national education school construction and maintenance program, to support the establishment o f a more effective and affordable approach to school maintenance. Maintenance o f buildings and equipment o f the project schools will be covered by the MOE recurrent budget. Future maintenance costs o f the project schools will be a very small share of the overall M O E operational budget and budget projections show that they do not constitute a sustainability problem. However, the sustainability o f maintenance costs of the total schools (14,000 schools) could become an issue during the short to medium term, as two-thirds of the public budget goes to transfers and subsidies and the share o f the line ministries i s quite small (MOE budget i s 3.5 percent in 2005). However, the expected increase in oil exports that make up two thirds of GDP, and the economic reform policies that are being introduced, such as privatization, restructuring SOEs, and phasing out subsidies program, are expected to stimulate sustainable growth over the mediumterm and provide resources for such types o f expenditure.  .. doc.abstracts: The main objective of the Third Emergency Education Project is to alleviate overcrowding in primary, and secondary schools through school construction, and provision of furniture and equipment. The project will also lay the groundwork for broader education reform, and system reconstruction. The project components are as follows: 1) School Construction - will finance the construction, and equipment and furniture provision in new schools; 2) Institutional Strengthening for System Development and Reform - will finance a comprehensive program to support education system development, and the design of a national school construction and maintenance program; and, 3) Project Management - will finance project implementation costs, including capacity building of the project management team in the Ministry of Education. In spite of the many project benefits, particularly that it will help improve the learning environment, major risks to the project are the unstable security and political environment, as well as the limited capacity of the government, and private sector. In the previous education projects in Iraq, capacity building provided by Bank staff during supervision missions, helped accelerate project preparation and implementation.
